init_text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion,

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: These are hygiene products that are fundamental to women’s health.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: And yet, if boys find out that pads and tampons are being provided in schools, you can be sure they will demand their own.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Furthermore, the implementation of any type of policy requires administration.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: In other words, school staff would have to be diverted from their work to provide pads and tampons.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: This would support school budgets and make school sustainable.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: This would be more fair and economical than using public funds or diverting school staff.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: We need to encourage them to develop the habit of bringing their own sanitary napkins or pads into school.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: schools should not be required to provide free pads and tampons to students.
